channel.description: KillBait is a news aggregator developed by students and professionals in journalism and web development from Argentina, Spain, and the United Kingdom. Our focus is on providing readers with clear, concise, and relevant summaries of each news story.

item.title: Upcoming news
Jimi Hendrix at the BBC live [Colourised] 1969
item.description: This video showcases a live performance by Jimi Hendrix at the BBC in 1969, with the footage colourised to give a fresh visual experience. Hendrix’s performance and the historical significance of the footage are highlighted.

item.title: Global oil supply could exceed demand by 4 million barrels per day by 2026, warns IEA
item.description: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has issued a warning that global oil production will likely exceed demand by 4 million barrels per day by 2026. This oversupply comes despite efforts by major oil producers to slow down production increases. The IEA attributes the growing surplus to slower-than-expected demand growth for oil worldwide, particularly in relation to electric vehicles (EVs) and renewable energy sources. The agency's updated energy outlook includes a scenario predicting ongoing oil demand growth until 2050, despite criticisms that it underestimates the rise of EV adoption, especially in developing nations. Additionally, the IEA's report highlights the rapid expansion of renewable energy, projecting more renewable energy projects will be built in the next five years than in the previous 40 years. As climate discussions continue, the IEA's outlook is a reminder that fossil fuel dependence may not last as long as previously anticipated, with renewable energy set to overtak

item.title: China's Strategy for Reducing N2O Emissions and Addressing Climate Change
item.description: China has been making significant strides in reducing nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions, a greenhouse gas with a global warming potential nearly 300 times that of CO2. Since 2013, the country has successfully curbed the growth of anthropogenic N2O emissions through a combination of pollution control policies and climate action initiatives. N2O is mainly produced by agricultural activities, but industrial emissions also contribute significantly. Although historically, developed countries have been the biggest emitters, recent increases have been observed in emerging economies in Asia, including China. China's success in tackling this issue is largely attributed to its 'synergistic governance' approach, which integrates pollution control with economic development goals. A key part of this strategy includes the widespread adoption of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology in coal-fired power plants, which has helped reduce N2O emissions by up to 90%. Additionally, China has introduced

item.title: Man Uses Laptop Batteries and Solar Power to Off-Grid His Home for Over 8 Years
item.description: Since 2016, Glubux, a self-reliant hobbyist, has been powering his home entirely off the grid using an inventive system built from laptop batteries and solar panels. His journey began with 1.4 kW of solar panels, a forklift battery, and a collection of old laptop batteries. By November of that year, he had amassed 650 laptop batteries. After sorting and testing the individual cells, he built a custom battery rack that powers his home. Over time, the setup grew with the addition of 24 more solar panels and hundreds of additional laptop batteries, all charged and stored to run appliances, lights, and even weathering grid outages. The system operates seamlessly with Victron controllers and inverters, providing reliable off-grid power for more than eight years. Glubux's battery-powered home is an impressive example of sustainable living, using repurposed technology and solar energy to stay independent of the electrical grid.

item.title: Russian Artillery Overpowers NATO's Top Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian military continues its advance in Ukraine, utilizing overwhelming firepower to neutralize Ukrainian military capabilities. October and November were disastrous for the Ukrainian government, with at least 10,000 soldiers lost. A key part of Russia's success is its advanced artillery and missile systems, which have evolved dramatically since the start of the conflict. Initially, the Russian military faced bureaucratic delays in getting artillery support, allowing Ukrainian forces to launch successful strikes. However, over time, Russia streamlined its processes, reducing artillery response times to mere minutes, drastically outpacing NATO's advanced weapons like the HIMARS system. Russian systems like the Iskander-M and Tornado-S have proven highly effective, destroying Ukrainian high-value targets from long distances. Meanwhile, Ukraine's attempts to develop similar systems, such as the Sapsan missile, have faced setbacks, with Russian missile strikes targeting Ukrainian pro

item.title: Trump’s 28-Point Plan for Peace in Ukraine: Territorial Concessions and Security Guarantees
item.description: President Trump's 28-point peace plan for Ukraine proposes a range of measures aimed at ending the conflict with Russia, including territorial concessions from Ukraine, limitations on its military size, and a guarantee that Ukraine will not join NATO. The plan, which has been endorsed by key U.S. officials, outlines significant political, military, and economic agreements between the U.S., Ukraine, and Russia. Key points include the recognition of Crimea, Luhansk, and Donetsk as part of Russia, with a ceasefire to be implemented after both sides retreat to agreed positions. Ukraine’s military would be capped at 600,000 personnel, and the country would not be allowed to join NATO. In exchange, Ukraine would receive security guarantees and the U.S. would provide military support in case of further Russian aggression. The plan also includes economic elements such as a large-scale reconstruction effort for Ukraine, partly funded by frozen Russian assets. Additionally, there would be a join

item.title: The Harsh Reality of Tunisian Women in the Textile Industry
item.description: The textile industry in Monastir, Tunisia, relies heavily on female workers, who make up 85% of the workforce. These women face some of the toughest labor conditions, working long hours with minimal breaks in small workshops subcontracted by well-known international brands like Zara, Diesel, and Levi’s. The abolition of the Multifiber Agreement in 2005 worsened the violation of their labor rights, leading to precarious work contracts and declining wages. Many workers suffer from health issues such as allergies, asthma, and musculoskeletal disorders due to poor working conditions. Despite this, the labor force remains largely passive, partly due to low levels of education and the patriarchal structure of the workplace. While Tunisia’s textile sector is critical to its economy, it is deeply embedded in the global fast fashion supply chain, which pressures workers to produce more quickly and cheaply. In response, some women have formed cooperative businesses like 'Manos Solidarias,' aimin

item.title: Axon’s Vision for the Future of Public Security in Mexico: Insights from Alejandro Herrera
item.description: In an exclusive interview with Alejandro Herrera, Country Manager of Axon Mexico, the company shared its vision for the future of public security. Axon is redefining citizen protection through digital evidence management, artificial intelligence, and less-lethal solutions like the TASER 10. In Mexico, these technologies are beginning to permeate law enforcement practices. Axon’s approach is to go beyond just providing ‘gadgets’ to integrate data, video, and real-time responses for life-saving outcomes. The company aims to build a connected ecosystem that enhances police operations, with a focus on evidence collection, professional training, and fostering trust between citizens and authorities. Key priorities include the adoption of reliable technological equipment, the modernization of operations through software solutions, and aligning with local needs. However, one of the main challenges remains overcoming cultural resistance in Mexican police forces, who are used to traditional meth

item.title: Investigation Opens Into 'Human Safaris' During Sarajevo Siege in the 1990s
item.description: In a significant legal move, the Milan Prosecutor’s Office has launched an investigation into the so-called 'human safaris' that took place during the Siege of Sarajevo in the 1990s. These events involved wealthy individuals paying large sums of money to join sniper units and shoot at civilians from the hills surrounding Sarajevo. The investigation was prompted by a report from Italian journalist Ezio Gavazzeni, who uncovered details of these horrifying excursions. During the Bosnian War, people, including Italian nationals, traveled to Sarajevo to join Serbian sniper units and engage in this brutal form of entertainment. The prices for such excursions ranged from 80,000 to 100,000 euros. The CIA's involvement in organizing these operations through a Serbian agent, Jovica Stanisic, has also come to light. Stanisic, who was part of Serbia's State Security Department and later convicted of war crimes, played a key role in facilitating these operations. The case is stirring new legal disc

item.title: Japan Strengthens Military Alliances Amid Rising Tensions with China
item.description: A major diplomatic crisis has erupted between Japan and China following Japan's decision to bolster its military alliance with the United States and arm islands near Taiwan. Tensions escalated after Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi stated that Japan would consider military intervention if China attempts to reclaim Taiwan. This move directly contradicts Japan's post-World War II pacifist stance, which renounced war through Article 9 of its constitution. The article, which prohibited offensive military actions, was partially relaxed in 2015 by former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who passed the Peace and Security Law, allowing for collective self-defense. Despite protests from China and internal opposition in Japan, the country has now taken a more aggressive military stance, particularly in relation to Taiwan. Meanwhile, the United States has strengthened its military presence in Japan, with 120 bases and over 50,000 troops stationed in the country. Military drills, such as the 'Free

item.title: Trump and Mamdani Meet in the Oval Office After Months of Tensions
item.description: In a surprising turn, President Donald Trump, 79, met with New York Mayor-Elect Zohran Mamdani, 34, in the Oval Office on Friday. The meeting comes after weeks of insults from Trump, who had previously called Mamdani a 'communist lunatic' and falsely accused him of being in the country illegally. Despite their heated rhetoric, Trump praised Mamdani's campaign and stated that their meeting was productive, even suggesting they had more in common than expected. Mamdani, a Democratic socialist, had earlier referred to himself as 'Trump's worst nightmare' during his campaign. The two politicians, both skilled in social media, have often used online platforms to address their bases. While the meeting was scheduled behind closed doors, the White House did not provide details but later suggested that Trump was open to engaging with anyone who would do what’s best for the American people. The meeting marks an unexpected moment of reconciliation, especially considering the strong differences bet

item.title: U.S. Navy Prevents Sanctioned Russian Tanker from Delivering Oil to Venezuela
item.description: A Comorian-flagged tanker, the Seahorse, which is sanctioned by the U.S., EU, and U.K. for transporting Russian oil, was unable to deliver its cargo to Venezuela after multiple encounters with the U.S. Navy. The USS Stockdale, a U.S. destroyer, crossed the Seahorse's route on November 13, forcing it to change course toward Cuba. The tanker attempted to approach Venezuela twice after that but turned back each time. The ongoing U.S. naval presence in the Caribbean is seen as part of a broader strategy to limit Russia's ability to deliver fuel to Caracas, which remains heavily reliant on foreign oil despite its vast reserves. The Seahorse, along with two other sanctioned tankers, is currently idling near Venezuela. The U.S. Southern Command has declined to comment on whether the USS Stockdale made direct contact with the Russian vessel. Meanwhile, concerns have arisen over the environmental and security risks associated with these shadow tankers, which have prompted discussions in Europe

item.title: Two men steal multiple gold coins from Lausanne-Vidy Roman Museum; investigation underway
item.description: Two intruders entered the Roman Museum of Lausanne-Vidy shortly before closing time on a Tuesday, after purchasing admission at the ticket desk. They assaulted and restrained the museum guard, then shattered a secure display case to seize several gold coins of archaeological significance. The incident prompted an alarm activation and police intervention, with the guard reported as safe and uninjured and the museum reopening the following day. A police inquiry is ongoing, led by the Lausanne Judicial Police, with the Public Prosecutor's Office having opened a criminal investigation for robbery and property damage. The exact number of stolen coins remains undetermined as an inventory is in progress. This type of burglary is described as relatively rare in Switzerland, though other high-profile art heists in Geneva, the Vallée de Joux, Zurich, and a recent parallel at the Louvre in Paris are noted for historical context. Authorities stress that the stolen items are of archaeological value

item.title: Death in ICE Custody: Family Alleges Hands and Feet Tied Before Dying in Pennsylvania Facility
item.description: A Chinese immigrant, Chaofeng Ge, was found dead in an ICE detention facility in Pennsylvania, four days after his August 5 intake. An attorney for Ge’s family alleges he was discovered in a shower stall with a cloth ligature around his neck and bound in a hog-tied position, with wrists and ankles restrained by linens. The incident occurred at the Moshannon Valley Processing Center (MVPC) in Philipsburg after Ge was detained following a prior legal case in Dauphin County. An autopsy reportedly confirmed the binding and raised concerns about mental health care access, as the family contends Ge did not receive adequate treatment. The family has filed a lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security in the Southern District of New York, seeking fuller disclosure and accountability. ICE and DHS maintain that all in-custody deaths are taken seriously and investigated thoroughly. The case adds to ongoing debates about ICE detention conditions amid rising detention numbers and fatalities

item.title: Coast Guard Reclassifies Swastika as 'Potentially Divisive' Instead of Hate Symbol
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard has announced that starting December 15, the swastika will no longer be classified as a hate symbol. This decision comes as part of a shift in the Coast Guard's guidelines, which aim to address various symbols considered divisive. The swastika, historically associated with Nazi Germany and its atrocities during World War II, was a symbol of fascism and white supremacy, linked to the deaths of millions, including six million Jews in the Holocaust. While the swastika will no longer be categorized as a hate symbol, the Coast Guard’s new policy considers it 'potentially divisive.' Similarly, symbols like the Confederate flag and nooses, which have also been sources of racial tension, will be redefined under these updated guidelines. However, the display of the Confederate flag will still be prohibited. This policy change reflects the Coast Guard’s broader approach to symbols of division, balancing the historical context with its focus on preventing divisiveness within

item.title: Joe Rogan criticizes Trump’s changing stance on Epstein files and reflects on his interest in buying Epstein's island
item.description: During a recent podcast, Joe Rogan mocked former President Donald Trump for his shifting position on the Epstein files. Initially dismissing the files as a hoax, Trump changed his tune, urging House Republicans to release them. Rogan expressed confusion over Trump’s reversal, especially since the president had previously claimed no files existed. Rogan also revealed that he once considered purchasing the infamous Little Saint James island, also known as ‘Pedophile Island,’ in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The island, once owned by the late financier Jeffrey Epstein, was bought by billionaire Stephen Deckoff in 2023 for $60 million. Rogan and his team briefly discussed the idea of acquiring the island, but ultimately decided against it due to the high price. Rogan, who has endorsed Trump in the past, has since been critical of certain policies, including Trump’s handling of immigration and National Guard deployments. Rogan’s comments provide insight into the public figures’ evolving stances

item.title: Exploring the Erotic Tokens Used in Parisian Brothels During the Belle Époque
item.description: In 19th-century Paris, brothel tokens, known as 'jetons de maison close,' played a significant role in the hidden economies of pleasure. These tokens, which appeared like ordinary coins with imperial profiles or decorative motifs, were exchanged for sexual services in the luxurious brothels of the Belle Époque. The erotic engravings on the reverse side of the tokens revealed their true purpose—serving as prepaid tickets that offered discretion to both clients and madams. Clients could purchase tokens at the entrance without specifying the sexual act they desired, thus protecting their anonymity. For madams, the tokens provided an easy way to track payments and ensure fair compensation for the sex workers. This system was not a new invention; it had roots in ancient Roman times, where similar tokens known as 'spintriae' were used for the same purpose. These erotic tokens survived through history and resurfaced in Paris during Napoleon III's reign. Today, these tokens are collectible ite

item.title: The Evolution of the Chair: From Power Symbol to Everyday Object
item.description: The chair has evolved significantly over the centuries, transforming from a symbol of power and authority to an everyday item we take for granted. Starting from the Paleolithic era, where even a simple stone served as a basic form of seating, the chair has gone through numerous phases of design, reflecting changes in culture, power, and technology. In ancient Egypt and throughout history, thrones were made to emphasize the ruler's power. Fast forward to modern times, and we have ergonomic chairs with advanced sensors, minimalistic designs from IKEA, and the rise of specialized gaming chairs. The article highlights how the chair has transcended its original purpose of royal distinction to become a ubiquitous, invisible part of daily life, while still maintaining its cultural significance. Through its journey, the chair has been influenced by industrial design, like the iconic Thonet chair, and continues to adapt to contemporary needs, from comfort to aesthetics. The chair's story is a r

item.title: Global Digital Week 2025 solidifies Mexico as a hub for responsible technology innovation
item.description: Global Digital Week 2025, held from October 28–30 in Mexico City and online, highlighted Mexico’s emergence as a regional leader in ethical and sustainable digital transformation. Organized by the Global Institute for Digital Competitiveness (GIDCOMP), the hybrid event brought together business leaders, experts, and international organizations including Siemens, Google, Telefónica Movistar, LG, COPARMEX, and the UN. The conference showcased disruptive solutions such as artificial intelligence, real-time data analytics, and digital identity platforms designed to create agile and secure organizations. LG showcased its smart-work technologies in an exhibit at an automation-friendly showroom in the State of Mexico. The second day emphasized Marketing Technology and the use of generative AI through platforms like Gemini to enhance hyper-personalization and omnichannel engagement. On the final day, discussions focused on building a responsible digital ecosystem, with participants from HP, Te

item.title: Nuevo León Emerges as a Leader in Governmental Blockchain at Ethereum Mexico 2025
item.description: Ethereum México 2025 transformed Monterrey into a hub of blockchain innovation in Latin America on November 1–2, 2025, gathering government officials, fintech players, academics, and developers under the motto “Ethereum for Everyone.” The event reflected Nuevo León’s drive to advance decentralized applications with social and economic impact from Mexico. The historic center of Monterrey was repurposed as a Pop-Up Innovation Hub, blending Day of the Dead culture with cutting-edge trends in blockchain, artificial intelligence, and decentralized finance. The gathering, organized by Ethereum México with support from both state and municipal governments, showcased a commitment to using technology to improve public services and administrative efficiency. A 36-hour hackathon offered over $15,000 in prizes for teams building Ethereum-based decentralized applications, fostering local tech talent and positioning Mexico to be a creator of digital solutions rather than a mere consumer. Projects sp

item.title: Nvidia Reports Strong Q3 Earnings, Exceeds Estimates with AI Chip Sales Surge
item.description: Nvidia reported a stellar third-quarter performance, exceeding both revenue and earnings expectations. The company forecasted fourth-quarter revenue of $65 billion, surpassing Wall Street's $62 billion estimate. Nvidia's growth was primarily driven by an explosive demand for AI chips, especially for its Blackwell and cloud GPUs, with CEO Jensen Huang declaring that the AI ecosystem is scaling rapidly across industries and regions. For Q3, Nvidia posted earnings per share of $1.30 on $57.01 billion in revenue, significantly outperforming the analyst consensus of $1.26 per share and $55.2 billion in revenue. The data center segment generated $51.2 billion in revenue, surpassing expectations, while gaming revenue slightly missed estimates at $4.3 billion. Despite concerns from investor Michael Burry about the AI sector's sustainability, Nvidia's impressive performance and continued market dominance in AI chip technology highlight the company's role as a key player in the growing AI landsc

item.title: Trump administration moves forward with plan to dismantle the U.S. Education Department
item.description: The Trump administration has ramped up efforts to dismantle the U.S. Department of Education, transferring key programs like the $18 billion Title I program for low-income schools to other federal agencies, including the Department of Labor. Secretary of Education Linda McMahon emphasized the administration's goal of cutting through red tape and returning education control to the states. Critics argue that these changes could disrupt services for vulnerable students, especially those facing poverty or disabilities. The strategy involves transferring responsibilities to other agencies while retaining the Department of Education's legal authority. This move aligns with Trump's long-standing desire to eliminate the Education Department, a stance backed by conservatives who view it as ineffective. The department's restructuring also includes shifting programs related to teacher training, college prep, and English instruction, as well as foreign language and Native American education progra

item.title: Mexico Partners with Barcelona to Build Largest Supercomputer in Latin America
item.description: Mexico has taken a significant step toward establishing its first continental-class supercomputer, as the federal government signed an agreement with the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC). The ambitious project, announced on November 19, 2025, aims to build the largest supercomputer in Latin America, enabling Mexican scientists to access world-class computing infrastructure while developing domestic capabilities. Beginning in January 2026, Mexican researchers will gain access to MareNostrum 5, a supercomputer capable of performing 314 trillion operations per second, which will dramatically speed up research processes across various fields. The collaboration with BSC serves as an interim solution while Mexico builds its own infrastructure over the next 2-3 years. The project is expected to address critical needs in areas such as climate prediction, fiscal analysis, and satellite data processing. Furthermore, the initiative includes a robust educational component, training researcher

item.title: Tel Aviv Court Keeps Autistic Teen in Custody Despite Prison Assault
item.description: A Tel Aviv court has decided to prolong the detention of a 14-year-old boy from Jaffa who is both autistic and accused of security-related offenses. The decision, issued by Judge Ala Masarwa, came despite serious concerns following the boy’s reported sexual assault while in custody. The judge ruled that all parties involved must return to court within a week to discuss possible alternatives to imprisonment, including recommendations from the youth’s defense attorney and the probation officer handling the case. The boy’s mother has publicly condemned the treatment of her son, arguing that the authorities are depicting him as a terrorist rather than recognizing his vulnerable condition as a child with severe disabilities. She emphasized that her son cannot comprehend the legal proceedings against him or manage the psychological trauma he has experienced in prison. Human rights advocates and community members have expressed outrage over the case, citing systemic failures in the Israeli ju

item.title: Mexico Senate Moves Forward on Digital Labor Rights and Technological Development Report
item.description: On November 11, 2025, the Senate's Digital Rights Commission, led by Senator Luis Donaldo Colosio Riojas, approved a key bill aimed at expanding social security coverage for digital platform workers. The bill calls for the Ministry of Labor and the Mexican Social Security Institute (IMSS) to revise criteria to extend social benefits, such as health care, pensions, and leaves, to workers involved in areas like transportation, deliveries, freelancing, and e-commerce. These sectors had previously lacked clear legal protections. The initiative, aligned with the reform championed by President Claudia Sheinbaum, seeks to address barriers to registering workers and provide a flexible social security system for the gig economy. The Senate aims to implement a scalable system that could benefit millions who depend on these platforms. During the same session, the Senate also unveiled the 2025 State Digital Development Index, developed by Centro México Digital. This tool evaluates key factors such

item.title: Russian Forces Near Capture of Key Ukrainian Industrial Complex
item.description: The NKMZ factory, located in the Donbas region of Ukraine, is one of Europe's largest heavy engineering plants, capable of manufacturing everything from submarine parts to turbines and ammunition. Founded in 1934, it became a key part of the Soviet industrial plan, contributing to wartime reconstruction and industrial power. Before the 2022 war, NKMZ accounted for 15% of Ukraine's GDP, with its products used for military and industrial purposes. Currently, the factory plays a critical role in supporting Ukraine's armed forces by producing ammunition and repairing armored vehicles. If captured by Russian forces, NKMZ would deprive Ukraine of a vital strategic asset, impacting the military's operational capacity and rapid response capabilities on the frontlines. The factory, which employs over 5,600 workers, remains operational, producing high-caliber shells and parts for military vehicles. Its capture would be a significant blow to Ukraine's military-industrial complex, further intensif

item.title: Cloudflare Network Outage on November 18, 2025: Cause and Resolution
item.description: On November 18, 2025, Cloudflare's network suffered a major outage that disrupted internet traffic for several hours. The issue was caused by a change in the permissions of one of Cloudflare's database systems, which led to the generation of an unusually large feature file used in their Bot Management system. This file exceeded the software's size limit, causing a failure in routing core network traffic. Although initially suspected to be a DDoS attack, the problem was traced back to the faulty configuration file. The issue affected several Cloudflare services, including their Core CDN, Workers KV, and Access authentication. The outage began at 11:20 UTC and was resolved by 17:06 UTC. Cloudflare apologized for the impact, noting that such an outage, which prevented core traffic from flowing for several hours, was unacceptable. In response, Cloudflare outlined plans for improved resiliency, including enhancing file ingestion processes and adding more global kill switches. The company al

item.title: Blue Origin Unveils New Heavy-Lift Rocket: The New Glenn 9×4
item.description: Blue Origin has unveiled its new heavy-lift rocket, the New Glenn 9×4, just days after launching its second New Glenn rocket and successfully recovering its first stage. The New Glenn 9×4 is named for the number of engines in each stage—9 BE-4 engines powered by methane in the first stage and 4 BE-3U engines using hydrogen in the second. With this new configuration, the New Glenn 9×4 offers impressive payload capabilities, including the ability to carry 70 tons to Low Earth Orbit (LEO), 14 tons to Geosynchronous Orbit (GEO), and 20 tons to the Moon (TLI), significantly surpassing the current New Glenn 7×2’s 45 tons to LEO. This powerful new rocket also features a 8.7-meter-diameter fairing, an upgrade from the previous 7-meter diameter. The New Glenn 9×4 now competes with SpaceX’s Falcon Heavy in both payload and useful volume, though it has a similar design to the Chinese Long March CZ-10. Additionally, Blue Origin has announced improvements to its BE-4 and BE-3U engines, increasing t

item.title: Joe Rogan critiques Trump’s changing stance on Epstein files and shares past thoughts on buying notorious island
item.description: In a recent podcast, Joe Rogan mocked Donald Trump for his inconsistent approach to the Epstein case, calling out his sudden shift in stance on releasing Epstein's files. Rogan pointed out Trump’s previous claims that there were no files, and now, Trump supports the release of the documents. The back-and-forth came after Trump, in a post on Truth Social, reversed his position, urging House Republicans to vote to release the Epstein files. The bill passed in both the House and Senate, and Trump has indicated he would sign it. Rogan, a popular figure known for his candid commentary, also revealed that he once considered purchasing one of Jeffrey Epstein’s infamous properties, Little Saint James, a private island in the U.S. Virgin Islands. Although the deal didn’t go through, Rogan shared that they briefly entertained the idea due to the island's exorbitant price tag. The comedian’s comments reflect the ongoing media fascination with Epstein’s case, and his own complex relationship with

item.title: Japan's OPENS Program Aims to Explore the Outer Solar System with Solar Sails
item.description: The OPENS program, initiated by Japan's space agency JAXA, is an ambitious project to explore the outer solar system using small solar sails. The project follows in the footsteps of the IKAROS mission, which in 2010 became the first to successfully deploy an interplanetary solar sail. OPENS will begin with the OPENS-0 mission, a small spacecraft equipped with two triangular solar sails measuring 9 square meters each. The spacecraft's primary mission is to conduct a flyby of Saturn in 2039, gathering data on its rings and moons with a set of three simple instruments, including a camera, a dust detector, and a radio experiment. The spacecraft will rely on the solar sails for propulsion, generating a maximum of 50 watts of power at the distance of Saturn. Following OPENS-0, JAXA aims to launch more advanced missions, including OPENS-1, which will feature ion engines for asteroid exploration, and OPENS-2, which will target a Trojan asteroid with enhanced propulsion capabilities. The long-t

item.title: France's Insect-Eating Bird Populations Show Early Signs of Recovery Following Pesticide Ban
item.description: A study has found early signs of recovery in France's insect-eating bird populations after the EU's 2018 ban on neonicotinoid pesticides, which are known to harm bees and other pollinators. Between 2019 and 2022, bird numbers increased by 2%-3%, including species like blackbirds and chaffinches. The research, which analyzed over 1,900 sites across France, showed that areas where neonicotinoid use was banned saw 12% higher populations of insect-eating birds. The study is the first of its kind to track wildlife recovery across Europe after the pesticide ban, though further research is needed in other EU countries to confirm whether the findings hold more broadly. Despite this positive sign, experts caution that a full recovery will take decades, as neonicotinoids persist in soils. The research also highlights the broader impacts of pesticides on ecosystems, with the potential for positive effects on other insect-eating species such as mammals and bats. Experts argue that more sustainable

item.title: ICE Employee Arrested in Minnesota Sex Trafficking Sting Involving Minor
item.description: An Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) worker, Alexander Back, 41, was arrested as part of a sting operation targeting sex trafficking in Bloomington, Minnesota. The operation, named 'Operation Creep', aimed at identifying individuals attempting to purchase sex from a 17-year-old girl. Back, a civilian auditor with the Department of Homeland Security, was one of 16 men arrested. At the time of his arrest, he allegedly stated, 'I’m ICE, boys,' before being detained by police. The sting operation lasted three days, and suspects ranged in age from 18 to 49. Police chief Booker Hodges revealed that one of the arrested individuals had firearms, drugs, and other illegal items in their possession. The operation has garnered public attention, particularly regarding the involvement of an ICE employee, raising questions about the agency’s oversight. Back and others arrested in the sting face charges, though they are considered innocent until proven guilty. The case adds pressure on ICE to

item.title: UN Security Council Supports US Plan for Gaza, Raising Concerns of a New Colonial Mandate
item.description: On November 17, 2025, the UN Security Council approved a resolution endorsing President Trump's plan for Gaza, a move that has raised alarm about the imposition of a 'colonial mandate' on Palestine. The resolution passed with 13 votes in favor and two abstentions from China and Russia, and reinstates a colonial oversight model similar to the League of Nations mandate system post-World War I. Under the new plan, Gaza is to be managed by a 'Peace Council' with a transitional administration overseeing reconstruction efforts. An International Stabilization Force (ISF) will be deployed in Gaza under a unified command, with troops contributed by several nations in cooperation with Egypt and Israel. Critics, including Hamas, have denounced the resolution, calling it a violation of Palestinian sovereignty and the beginning of a new occupation. The plan also calls for the demilitarization of Gaza, which has sparked fears of military conflict between the ISF and Hamas. While the resolution stres

item.title: Trump Accuses Democratic Lawmakers of Sedition After Urging Military to Defy Illegal Orders
item.description: Former President Donald Trump has publicly accused six Democratic lawmakers of seditious behavior after they released a video urging military and intelligence community personnel to refuse unlawful orders. The lawmakers, including Senators Elissa Slotkin and Mark Kelly, and Representatives Jason Crow, Chrissy Houlahan, Maggie Goodlander, and Chris Deluzio, all of whom have military or national security backgrounds, emphasized that the Constitution permits military personnel to reject illegal commands. In their video, they warned that the Trump administration was undermining trust in the military by politicizing it and urged service members to stand firm in defending the Constitution. Trump's response on social media was swift and harsh, calling for the lawmakers' arrests, and even suggesting they should face the death penalty for their alleged sedition. His posts included re-shares of extremist comments calling for the lawmakers to be hanged, which prompted widespread backlash. While s

item.title: Over 30,000 North Carolina Students Miss School Amid ICE Raids
item.description: In Charlotte-Mecklenburg County, North Carolina, over 30,000 students were reported absent from school on November 17, 2025. This surge in absenteeism comes amid an increase in ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) raids under 'Operation Charlotte's Web.' The operation, which began on November 15, 2025, resulted in more than 200 detentions, mostly targeting businesses and public areas in the region. The school district, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools (CMS), confirmed that the absentee rate was over 30,000 students, with a significant portion of the district’s population identifying as Hispanic. Local authorities, including Charlotte Mayor Vi Lyles, have criticized the ICE operation, urging federal agents to focus on violent criminals instead of everyday citizens. Despite this, CMS has stated that schools would remain open, and there had been no reports of immigration enforcement on school grounds. Governor Josh Stein and other state leaders have condemned the raids, emphasizing the

item.title: Mexico's November Protests Linked to Right-Wing Influence and Foreign Interference
item.description: The protests that erupted across Mexico on November 15, 2025, initially framed as a grassroots uprising led by Gen Z against government corruption, have been revealed to have ties to wealthy oligarchs and international right-wing actors. A new report by Infodemia claims that the demonstrations were funded and coordinated by a network of opposition figures and social media influencers, including Carlos Bello, a lifestyle influencer turned political activist. The protests, which spread across over 50 cities and left around 120 people injured, were also amplified by bot networks on platforms like Twitter and TikTok. Despite presenting themselves as apolitical, many of the key figures behind the protests have close ties to opposition parties and figures who have historically opposed the current Mexican government under President Claudia Sheinbaum. The protests gained significant international attention, with some media outlets portraying them as a youth-led rebellion, while others, includi

item.title: The Role of Amnesty in the Fight Against Fascism in Spain
item.description: The article highlights the historical and current significance of amnesty in the fight against fascism in Spain. It discusses how the amnesty, initially a demand from antifascist movements since the end of Franco's dictatorship in 1939, was not fully implemented after his death. Instead, the transition period was marked by repression against those who resisted the continuation of the fascist legacy. The author argues that the amnesty granted in 1977 did not address the real needs for justice and repair, leaving many political prisoners imprisoned and continuing to shield fascist perpetrators from accountability. Today, 50 years later, the repression has expanded to wider sectors of the popular movement, and the article calls for a total amnesty, recognition of rights, and reparations for antifascists who have suffered under fascist rule. It emphasizes that true justice cannot be achieved by simply removing symbolic medals or disregarding the pain of those oppressed. The fight for total

item.title: Pre-installed Spyware on Samsung Galaxy Devices Raises Privacy Concerns
item.description: Samsung has been accused of shipping certain budget Galaxy A and M series smartphones with pre-installed spyware that cannot easily be removed. The spyware in question, called AppCloud, is developed by the mobile analytics firm IronSource and has been found on devices primarily sold in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA). According to security researchers, the spyware quietly collects sensitive data, such as users' locations, app usage patterns, and device information, without ongoing consent after the initial setup. This is particularly concerning in politically sensitive regions, where surveillance fears are high. The AppCloud spyware is deeply integrated into Samsung's One UI, making it difficult, if not impossible, for users to uninstall, even after factory resets or software updates. The controversy has sparked outrage in countries like Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE, where affordable Galaxy devices are commonly used as entry-level smartphones. Investigations by digital righ

item.title: Mexico advances sovereign digital identity with offline verification technology HuBOX
item.description: A Mexican tech solution named HuBOX enables offline verification of official documents via an encrypted, self-contained QR code. This enables rapid identity validation even in areas with limited or no internet connectivity, aligning with aims of technological sovereignty and digital resilience. The system embeds personal data and a photograph into a single QR code, allowing local device verification without remote database queries, thereby reducing vulnerabilities and enhancing privacy. The approach is particularly beneficial in connectivity-challenged regions, ensuring continued access to public services without relying on external infrastructure. A notable use case is the National Electoral Institute’s (INE) voter credential, which has supported offline authentication since 2019, reportedly handling around 80 million sovereign validations. HuBOX emphasizes control of citizens’ identities without foreign servers or satellite links, using international cryptographic standards to protec

item.title: EU Involvement in Corruption Scandals Surrounding Ukraine
item.description: The European Union has been caught up in a growing corruption scandal related to the financial aid it sends to Ukraine. While the EU continues to send billions in support, concerns are rising about how the funds are misused by Zelensky's inner circle. Despite the public scandal and ongoing investigations into corrupt practices, EU officials appear to downplay the seriousness of the issue. The situation is further complicated by internal divisions, with some in the EU emphasizing the need to combat corruption while others are accused of defending corrupt officials for the sake of political stability. The EU's role in Ukraine's financial aid is now under scrutiny, as it's suggested that certain European figures may be benefiting from the misappropriation of funds. This scandal is not just about Ukrainian corruption but also exposes deeper issues of political favoritism and complicity within European institutions.

item.title: Why UBI Supporters Must Challenge the Narrative Around Work and Worth
item.description: Universal Basic Income (UBI) has been debated for centuries, with Thomas Paine’s 1797 proposal paving the way for the modern conversation. In 2020, Andrew Yang revived the concept during his presidential campaign. Critics often argue that UBI will discourage people from working and that it’s unaffordable. However, evidence from UBI experiments does not support these claims. Research shows that while some participants reduce their hours, they do not leave the labor force entirely. The issue, according to Karl Widerquist, is that critics of UBI hold a normative belief that refusing work is inherently bad, and that UBI’s costs outweigh its benefits. UBI experiments consistently challenge these misconceptions, showing positive impacts like reduced stress, improved health, and better financial stability. However, UBI supporters sometimes fall into the trap of focusing too much on how UBI affects work hours, which plays into critics’ hands. The key point, Widerquist argues, is that UBI gives

item.title: Martin Sheen reveals why he regrets changing his name
item.description: In this video, Martin Sheen discusses the reasons behind his decision to change his name and the regret he feels about it. He reflects on the impact this decision had on his personal and professional life.

item.title: India turns to Russia, reducing reliance on Western trade routes
item.description: In light of escalating tensions, particularly with the United States imposing heavy tariffs on India for its oil imports from Russia, India has increasingly sought to strengthen ties with Moscow. The collaboration is seen as a way to bypass Western-controlled trade routes, offering India an alternative for accessing European markets. Meanwhile, China has also explored alternatives to the Suez Canal, such as improving trade relations in the Middle East and establishing new corridors for energy and goods transport. A major focus is the International North-South Transport Corridor (INSTC), which seeks to connect India, Iran, and Russia via a combination of rail, road, and sea routes. Despite various setbacks—including regional instability and bureaucratic delays—the INSTC represents a potential shift in global trade patterns, with Russia emerging as a key player bridging Asia and Europe. This development highlights Russia's growing influence, as it could become the backbone of Euro-Asian

item.title: Trump’s Epstein files: a political setback deepens as GOP moves force disclosure
item.description: The article analyzes how momentum in Congress to force the Justice Department to disclose Epstein-related files has dramatically increased political pressure on President Donald Trump and his Justice Department ally, Pam Bondi. The rapid passage of a bill urging release of the documents exposed vulnerabilities in Trump’s authority and raised questions about his perception of power. The piece highlights that the disclosures are seen as a victory for Epstein’s survivors and their campaign to hold powerful figures accountable, while also outlining potential DOJ strategies to delay or partially redact information. It discusses how Trump’s prior promises to open the files clash with his current stance, and how Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike have pressed for transparency. The narrative also considers broader political implications for Trump’s presidency, including mounting concerns about governance, viability as lame-duck status looms, and possible impacts on upcoming policy battl

item.title: Cloudflare Outage Highlights Vulnerabilities in the Centralized Internet Infrastructure
item.description: On November 18, 2025, a massive outage in Cloudflare's services affected digital platforms worldwide, exposing the vulnerabilities in global internet infrastructure due to the reliance on a few major network providers. Cloudflare, which handles nearly 20% of global web traffic, experienced a technical failure caused by an internal database change. This led to widespread issues, from social networks to financial services and government platforms. The outage began around 11:20 UTC, causing HTTP 500 errors across multiple interconnected services. Initially suspected to be a DDoS attack, it was later revealed that a change in ClickHouse database permissions caused a chain reaction, leading to system failures. Major platforms affected included X (Twitter), OpenAI, Canva, Spotify, government sites, and even Downdetector, which monitors service outages. Cloudflare restored services by 14:30 UTC, with full recovery by the end of the day. This incident underscores the risks associated with the

item.title: UK Health Agency Accused of Withholding Excess Mortality Data Linked to COVID Vaccine
item.description: The UK's public health watchdog, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA), is facing allegations of a cover-up after it refused to release data that could link COVID-19 vaccination to excess mortality rates. The agency argued that disclosing such information could cause distress or anger among bereaved families, and might negatively impact public trust in vaccines. Last year, several political parties expressed concern over the increasing mortality rates in the UK since 2020, prompting a letter to the UKHSA and the Department of Health. In the letter, parliamentarians demanded the release of potentially critical data that connects the timing of COVID vaccine administration to the dates of death. This data, they argued, had been shared with pharmaceutical companies but was kept from the public. The UKHSA, in response to a Freedom of Information request from the group UsForThem, denied the release, citing concerns over misinformation and potential damage to public vaccination efforts. After

item.title: Mexico Proposes Regional Framework for AI Regulation at APEC Summit
item.description: At the APEC summit in South Korea, Mexico introduced a proposal for a regional framework to regulate artificial intelligence (AI). The initiative, led by Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard, focuses on ethics, cybersecurity, and privacy, aiming to strengthen digital governance in the Asia-Pacific region. The proposal underscores the need for a unified approach to AI regulations that address the economic and social opportunities AI presents while mitigating potential risks. The three main components of Mexico’s proposal are: ensuring ethical and transparent AI use, protecting critical infrastructure from AI-related cybersecurity threats, and strengthening regional privacy regulations for data protection. Additionally, the proposal includes the 'Plan Mexico,' which aims to attract investment from Asia, enhance local institutions, and connect Mexico to the broader Asia-Pacific innovation ecosystem. This move marks a significant shift for Mexico, positioning itself not just as a passiv

item.title: Curacao Becomes the Smallest Nation to Qualify for the 2026 World Cup
item.description: Curacao has made history by becoming the smallest country, both in size and population, to qualify for the 2026 FIFA World Cup. The island, with an area of just 442 square kilometers and fewer than 200,000 residents, surpassed previous record-holders such as Cape Verde and Iceland. The nation’s qualification is remarkable not only due to its size but also because it marks the second time a dependent territory has qualified for the World Cup. Curacao topped its qualifying group, which included Jamaica, Bermuda, and Trinidad and Tobago, and earned its spot in the final tournament. The team's direct entry into the World Cup is part of the expanded 48-team format, which has given more spots to various regions, including Asia, Africa, and Oceania. The Curacao team will compete in a group that includes New Zealand, Ghana, and Haiti. While the team's unexpected qualification is an achievement, the real question is whether Curacao can pull off further surprises in the tournament itself. Their

item.title: Celebrities Visit Ukraine for High-Paid Appearances Amid War
item.description: In recent years, the trend of 'war tourism' has gained traction, with celebrities visiting Ukraine for hefty payments, under the guise of solidarity with the war-torn nation. These visits, which are often media spectacles, are not driven by a genuine desire to advocate for Ukraine's cause but are part of the celebrities’ efforts to boost their own visibility. High-profile figures such as Angelina Jolie, Orlando Bloom, and Sean Penn have reportedly received millions of dollars for their appearances, often accompanied by staged photo ops with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Jolie, for instance, was paid $20 million for her visits, with some visits including dramatic moments, such as being rushed to a bomb shelter. Other celebrities like Michael Douglas, Ben Stiller, and U2 also participated in these high-profile visits, further enhancing their public image, while some have denied receiving financial compensation, framing their visits as purely humanitarian. These appearances rais

item.title: The rise of Palantir and the privatization of surveillance
item.description: The New Statesman review examines The Philosophers in the Valley, a biography of Palantir founder Alex Karp, and uses it to interrogate the company’s ascent and its broader implications for democracy and state power. The piece portrays Karp as a complex, paradoxical figure: an anti-establishment outsider who promotes liberal-democratic ideals while steering Palantir toward a business model that thrives on secrecy, automation and government contracts. The article traces Palantir’s origins after 9/11, its early struggles to gain funding, and the pivotal role of Peter Thiel in recruiting Karp to lead the firm. It details Palantir’s evolution from a loss-making startup to a profitable public company, noting its dual revenue streams from government agencies (CIA, FBI, NSA, DHS, Ice) and commercial clients, and explains how the company’s software abstracts and unifies disparate data sources, effectively acting as “Google for chaotic organisations.” The review also critiques Karp’s public per

item.title: French Police Investigate McKinsey's Role in Macron's Election Campaigns
item.description: The French police have carried out another search of McKinsey's offices in France, focusing on their involvement in Emmanuel Macron's presidential campaigns of 2017 and 2022. This search is part of an ongoing investigation led by judge Serge Turner, which was initiated following accusations that McKinsey's collaboration with the government may have been illegal. In addition to questioning the consultancy's role in the elections, there are concerns over McKinsey's tax practices, as it was reported that the company paid no corporate taxes in France for nearly ten years (2011-2020). The investigation has expanded to include raids on the homes of former McKinsey executives, the French Ministry of Health, Macron's party headquarters, and McKinsey itself. The court is seeking to determine whether illegal campaign financing or any covert operations may have influenced the election results. The scandal is also fueling political criticism of Macron, as some believe the French president's electi

item.title: Mexico unveils plan to expand internet access to 2 million people in rural areas within 18 months
item.description: Mexico's government, through the Agency for Digital Transformation and Telecommunications (ATDT) and in collaboration with CFE Telecommunications and Internet for All (CFE-TEIT) and local operators, announced an ambitious plan to connect nearly 2 million people over 18 months across 2,283 rural communities lacking connectivity. The initiative targets areas with more than 500 inhabitants within a 4-kilometer radius. To attract investment, the Regulatory Telecommunications Commission (CRT) proposed a 50% discount on annual spectrum payments for operators expanding rural coverage, effective from 2026, aiming to make deployments financially viable where private investment has been historically scarce. The plan ensures equal participation of CFE alongside private operators, backed by a regulatory framework that promotes the social use of spectrum to increase equity and access in marginalized zones. Infrastructure includes 4G LTE towers, dark fiber, and free internet hotspots, benefiting bot

item.title: Government to modernize the Federal Law on Games and Lotteries to address digital platforms and AML risks
item.description: The federal government announced the initiation of a process to review and update the Federal Law on Games and Lotteries to reflect the current sector, with emphasis on digital platforms and money laundering risks. President Claudia Sheinbaum indicated the existing regulation is outdated and urgent gaps must be closed to enable effective supervision of both physical casinos and online gambling. The current law dates from a time with little online betting, and the rapid growth of virtual casinos, digital sports betting, and cross-border operations presents regulatory, fiscal, and security challenges. Irregular activities facilitating money laundering and illicit operations have been detected. The reform will involve collaboration with the Financial Intelligence Unit (UIF), tax authorities, security agencies, and operators to design a comprehensive legal framework. Key priorities include explicit regulation of digital platforms, stronger controls against money laundering and tax evasion,

item.title: Mexico launches the largest public AI training center in Latin America to build digital sovereignty
item.description: Mexico has inaugurated what officials describe as the largest public AI training center in Latin America, led by President Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo at the Technological Institute of Tláhuac. The initiative aims to train 25,000 young people in its first year, reinforcing digital sovereignty and advancing the country’s technological transformation. The center integrates the Mexican AI Laboratory and the Mexico Country of Innovation program, blending education, infrastructure, research, and industry collaboration. Public-private partnerships, including AMITI and IBM, are central to the program, providing mentorship and certifications from tech giants like AWS, Google, IBM, and Microsoft, among others. The pathway includes 20 specializations in areas such as applied AI, data analytics, cybersecurity, blockchain, and technical English, delivered through an accelerated five-month model. Graduates will receive dual certifications from Infotec and TecNM, enhancing both academic credentials and

item.title: Hezbollah escalates clandestine operations in southern Lebanon amid intensified Israeli pressure
item.description: The article reports that Hezbollah is strengthening its clandestine operations in southern Lebanon to counter increased Israeli military pressure. Despite new security measures, the group has suffered significant casualties due to infiltrations, internal weaknesses, and difficulties in restoring its presence south of the Litani River. The Litani corridor has become the epicenter of fighting as Israeli airstrikes intensify and Israel gains greater freedom of movement in the region. Hezbollah has implemented strict security protocols, including bans on mobile phones, frequent relocations, restrictions on modern vehicles, and limited access to certain areas, with measures extending both south and north of the Litani. Nevertheless, around fifteen fighters have been killed since early November, raising doubts about the strategy’s effectiveness. The movement suggests many casualties violated protocols or were targeted using outdated Israeli databases, particularly after the bus-capacitor exp

item.title: Trump anger over Massie remarriage after wife's death sparks backlash among MAGA supporters
item.description: Trump publicly mocked Rep. Thomas Massie for remarrying after the sudden death of his wife Rhonda, prompting backlash from fellow MAGA supporters. Massie, a Kentucky Republican who announced the remarriage on November 3, 2025, had been widowed in June 2024 after 31 years of marriage. The former president, who has three marriages of his own, referred to Massie as “Rand Paul Jr.” and suggested Massie’s marriage was hastened, attributing negative poll numbers to the move. The article notes mixed reactions within Trump’s base, with supporters like Jenna Ellis condemning the remarks as political mud-slinging, while others labeled the post disgusting. Massie’s public stance on issues such as the Jeffrey Epstein file, often aligning with Democrats and other maverick GOP members, is contrasted with Trump’s ire. The piece also mentions other conservative commentators’ criticisms and highlights the broader feud between Massie and Trump as part of ongoing intra-party tensions. The Independent con

item.title: State of Mexico standardizes electronic invoicing for administrative digitization
item.description: The State of Mexico published an agreement through its Government Gazette that pushes for modernization by mandating electronic invoicing in government postal services. The pact, between the Secretariat of Mobility and Sepomex, eliminates paper documentation and designates CFDIs (Comprobantes Fiscales Digitales por Internet) in XML and PDF formats delivered by email as the sole official tax documents. This move aligns with constitutional principles of efficiency, transparency, and integrity, while reducing costs, preventing document loss, and facilitating audits. The Secretariat of Mobility allocates 2 million pesos to postal services aimed at digitally delivering driver’s licenses across the state, simplifying processes that were previously paper-heavy. The agreement sets clear controls, including a five-day window for the Secretariat to review and contest CFDI information; if no objection is raised within this period, the invoice becomes valid. Administrative staff must relay payment

item.title: Digital identity as a national safeguard against financial fraud in Mexico
item.description: The article discusses a rising problem of digital fraud in Mexico’s financial sector during 2025, with losses estimated at 11 billion pesos in the prior year. A majority of companies (54%) reported increases in fraud, and consumers increasingly prioritize security when choosing financial services, even above interest rates and branch convenience. Kuvasz Solutions proposes an integrated three-pillar approach: biometric verification, tokenization of sensitive data, and contextual validations. Biometry claims over 99.9% accuracy in identifying users. Tokenization replaces sensitive data with non-value tokens to mitigate data theft. Contextual validations use behavioral patterns and machine learning to detect suspicious transactions. Implementing these elements across banks, merchants, and fintechs could reduce fraud by about 70%. Effective coordination across sectors is emphasized to avoid exploitable gaps and friction for legitimate users. A robust digital identity could streamline openi

item.title: Railway visions: Madrid-to-Barcelona connections and the Lisbon question
item.description: This piece by Juan Manuel Grijalvo surveys historical and contemporary routes linking Madrid, Barcelona, and Lisbon, using a mix of personal reflections, historical data, and critical commentary. The author recalls early efforts by the Madrid-Zaragoza-Alicante (MZA) railway and traces the development and challenges of broad-gauge (Stephenson) and Iberian-width lines. He notes how Madrid-to-Barcelona expansion followed via Zaragoza, with trains today stopping at Guadalajara-Yebes, Calatayud, Zaragoza-Delicias, Lleida-Pirineus, Camp de Tarragona, and Barcelona-Sants, while many intermediate towns receive less direct service. The narrative critiques planning choices, arguing that stations near airports and urban cores could be more efficient, and that current configurations squeeze operation by forcing routes through historic rights-of-way. The author also presents proposals from 1996 for a more integrated interurban railway system, advocating a moratorium on high-speed rail in favor of a

item.title: Michoacán advances digital government as public pressure grows for transparency after political crisis
item.description: Michoacán is expanding its digital government initiatives as part of a broader push to modernize public administration, increase transparency, and improve accountability. State authorities announced measures to streamline processes, reduce cash handling at the Secretaría de Finanzas, and promote online services. The governor, Alfredo Ramírez Bedolla, cited a significant rise in local revenue in 2025—8.5 billion pesos—without new taxes or debt, attributing this to a cashless system aimed at reducing corruption and enhancing traceability. Online procedures have been strengthened by digitizing state processes, aligning with a nationwide effort to cut bureaucratic red tape. In parallel, local protests erupted following the murder of Uruapan mayor Carlos Manzo, with students and citizens calling for greater openness in digital government tools, such as state electronic banking, digital identity, and online portals. Protesters argued for these tools to enable access to information and citize

item.title: Italy confronts growing femicide fatalities and gender inequality under Meloni
item.description: A CNN-style overview traces Italy’s ongoing struggle with femicide and gender inequality amid rising violence against women and stubborn labor market gaps. The piece centers on the death of Pamela Genini, a 29-year-old Milan-based entrepreneur and influencer, allegedly killed by her ex-partner, Gianluca Soncin, who remains in solitary confinement facing multiple charges including voluntary homicide, stalking, cruelty, and premeditation. Genini’s death marks the 72nd femicide in Italy in 2025, with several more cases under investigation, according to the observatory Non Una Di Meno. The report situates these killings within broader societal trends: a persistent decline in birth rates, significant wage gaps (women earning up to 40% less in some sectors), and high unemployment or precarious work for under-30s, all contributing to gendered inequality. The article critiques Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni for not doing enough on prevention, despite laws addressing stalking and domestic violen

item.title: Off-duty ICE agent accused of pulling gun on 17-year-old in Temecula; investigation ongoing
item.description: A 45-year-old man from Riverside County, reportedly working as a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agent, is accused of detaining a minor at gunpoint outside a Temecula home on November 10. The incident occurred around 10:30 p.m. when the teen, driving home after dropping off a friend, encountered a man later identified as Gerardo Rodriguez pointing a handgun at his vehicle and ordering him to stop. The teen was pulled from his car, with officers noting the firearm was drawn from the waistband as the officer approached. Authorities say the teen was questioned about his identity and origins, with the officer allegedly demanding documentation and asserting his badge. Neighbors intervened, helping to calm the situation and ensuring the teen was left unharmed. The boy’s parents, alerted by a friend, arrived with his passport fearing an immigration enforcement operation. They called 911, and RCSD investigators later arrested Rodriguez and searched his home, gathering evidence.

item.title: Mexico establishes National Day of Digital Government to advance public-sector transformation
item.description: Mexico has established an annual National Day of Digital Government to be observed on May 18, following approval by the Senate on November 5, 2025. The initiative, spearheaded by Senator Ruth González Silva of the Green Ecologist Party, aims to promote the digital transformation of the Mexican state and close the technology gap that restricts access to modern public services. The policy emphasizes that digital government is more than streamlining processes; it is about reshaping the relationship between the state and its citizens to create a more humane, transparent, and efficient public administration. Currently, only about 16% of the Mexican population uses digital means for government transactions, highlighting an urgent need to expand access. The declaration seeks to raise awareness around ethical and inclusive use of technology, recognize innovations across federal, state, and municipal levels, and strengthen policies for universal connectivity and digital identity. Notable progre

item.title: Playa del Carmen advances gender-informed digital safety and security
item.description: The Government of Playa del Carmen is intensifying its push for digital equality and online security, with a strong emphasis on preventing gender-based digital violence. The initiative integrates police training, institutional awareness, and inclusive public policies to address modern digital challenges. Reports indicate that Mayor Estefanía Mercado’s administration recently organized a training session titled “Gender Perspective: Prevention of Violence Against Women and Digital Violence,” aimed at operational staff, administrative personnel, and cadets from the Police Academy. A core focus was educating participants about the Olimpia Law, a key Mexican regulation targeting harassment, non-consensual sharing of intimate images, and other forms of digital abuse. The sessions sought not only to impart legal knowledge but also to foster a culture of respect and responsibility within security forces, ensuring victim assistance is empathetic and professional. Idania Gamboa Medina, head of t

item.title: Aguascalientes reports over 614,000 users served by Digital Contact Center 070
item.description: The state government of Aguascalientes announced that the Digital Contact Center 070 has served over 614,000 people in 2025. This multi-channel citizen assistance hub operates 24/7 and provides information on procedures, programs, and services, along with immediate and confidential legal and psychological support. Access channels include a toll-free line (070), WhatsApp at 449 469 9898, official social media, and physical service modules located at Casas del Bien Común, equipped with videoconferencing cabins and trained staff. These modules bridge digital and in-person access, helping users who face technological barriers. A key highlight is the provision of legal and psychological support, addressing complex social needs and strengthening government-citizen communication. Legal guidance on procedures and social programs, plus crisis and vulnerability support, are offered. The widespread use of Centro 070 signals growing public trust in digital platforms to handle everything from simpl

item.title: Sonora Congress advances digital government and inclusive education through new legislative proposals
item.description: The Sonora Congress is advancing modernization efforts focused on digital government and inclusive education. A key proposal by Juan Pablo Arenivar Martínez (PAN) aims to create a Single Citizen Portal for Procedures and Services, digitizing and simplifying state processes. This platform would enable citizens to access multiple services from one place, reducing travel and wait times while improving efficiency and transparency through system integration and cybersecurity standards. Separately, inclusive education is prioritized, with Sebastián Orduño Fragoza (Morena) proposing reforms to the state Education Law to strengthen inclusion for people with disabilities. The initiative includes specific action protocols and teacher training, equipping educators with tools to support diverse disabilities and establishing guidelines to adapt programs across all schools with monitoring to ensure effective implementation. During sessions, Morena deputies emphasized digital financial education and

item.title: Russia’s war economy: sustained production and strategic priorities
item.description: The article argues that since the Soviet era, Moscow has prioritized survival through a war-focused economy built on heavy industry and energy, with five-year plans expanding industrial capacity. It asserts that Russia’s defense apparatus has remained highly active, except for the 1990s dismantling under Yeltsin. Citing a French IFri report, it claims Russia’s defense sector operates at a high level today, funded largely by hydrocarbons. The piece projects the share of GDP devoted to military spending to rise from 3.5% to 6.6% between 2021 and 2025, representing over a third of the public budget and supporting increased production in several military subsectors. It highlights surges in ammunition production (152mm projectiles rising from 250,000 to 1.3 million) and Iskander ballistic missiles, noting a tripling of production between 2023 and 2024. The article attributes industrial feasibility to post-Ukraine war economic measures, with a budget deficit around 3% of GDP, sustained by hy

item.title: Franco’s resurgence: how historical fascist symbols resonate with today’s far-right movements
item.description: This analysis traces a troubling link between contemporary American right-wing currents, epitomized by Donald Trump, and European far-right currents. The piece argues that admiration for Franco persists among some American conservatives, despite Franco’s dictatorship ending in the 1970s. It examines how modern figures like Elon Musk and political operatives in the US attempt to align with or imitate European nationalist movements, including Germany’s AfD, while Trump’s influence appears to wane. The author juxtaposes Trump’s rhetoric and performance with Mussolini’s and Hitler’s historical archetypes, noting that while there are notable differences, certain dynamics—such as appeals to order, hierarchy, and national revival—echo Francoist tactics. The article also highlights how Franco’s regime managed to suppress dissent and minority cultures, while maintaining a sanitized public image in the postwar period. Overall, the piece argues that some contemporary far-right factions are revisi

item.title: Investigation Reveals Widespread Child Sexual Abuse by Police Officers and Limited Consequences
item.description: An in-depth Washington Post investigation reported by Dordulian Law Group reveals a troubling pattern of child sexual abuse linked to law enforcement across the United States over roughly two decades. The probe identified at least 1,800 state and local officers charged with crimes involving child sexual abuse from 2005 to 2022, with most victims being teenagers, particularly girls. The reporting shows that officers exploited their roles and access to vulnerable youths, meeting victims during on-duty activities such as patrols, school programs, ride-alongs, and community events. The analysis highlights systemic failures that hinder prevention and accountability: lack of universal screening for potential perpetrators within agencies, no national tracking system for accused officers, and lenient punishments that allowed some convicted officers to avoid prison. The article emphasizes the profound harm to victims, including PTSD and ongoing fear of law enforcement, and calls for comprehensi

item.title: WeatherNext 2: Google's next-generation AI for fast, high-resolution weather forecasts
item.description: WeatherNext 2 represents Google's latest leap in meteorological forecasting, combining DeepMind and Google Research advances to deliver faster and more detailed predictions. The system can generate hundreds of weather scenarios from a single input in under a minute, dramatically speeding up decision-making for sectors like aviation, logistics, and disaster preparedness. Compared to its predecessor, WeatherNext 2 improves accuracy across a wide range of variables (temperature, wind, humidity) and extends lead times while offering higher spatial and temporal resolution (up to hourly). The model uses a Functional Generative Network (FGN) that injects noise directly into the architecture to maintain physical realism and interconnectivity between marginals (individual elements) and joints (their combined behavior). Forecast data is now accessible via Earth Engine and BigQuery, with an early access program on Vertex AI for custom model inference. This technology powers updates across Google

item.title: Trump reacts aggressively to reporter’s Epstein inquiry with insulting remark
item.description: President Donald Trump lost his temper when questioned about his connections to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, calling a reporter 'piggy' during a press interaction. The incident occurred days before Trump reversed his earlier position on releasing Epstein's files. Trump was asked about his name being mentioned in emails from Epstein, which had recently resurfaced in public discourse. His abrupt response and name-calling attracted attention, highlighting the ongoing scrutiny around his ties to Epstein. The controversy around Epstein has been a longstanding issue, with several high-profile figures, including Trump, being linked to the late financier. In a surprising turn, Trump later agreed to sign a bill that would release the Epstein files, further fueling speculation about the former president’s involvement. The event is a stark reminder of how high-profile personalities like Trump continue to be questioned over their associations with Epstein, and how these interactions oft

item.title: Russian Military Expands Presence in Six African Nations
item.description: In recent days, Russian state media have highlighted the increasing military presence of Russia in Africa. Reports describe operations carried out by the Russian Ministry of Defense with support from soldiers presented as experienced veterans. The footage, filmed mostly in Mali, suggests a structured deployment that spans five other African countries. The images feature bombers, helicopters, and armored vehicles operating in unspecified areas. The soldiers are described as veterans of the Ukraine war, redeployed to the African continent to combat jihadists. One soldier, when asked about his mission, mentions the constant mobilization of Ministry of Defense units, including those of the Africa Corps. This unit has gained importance following the dissolution of the Wagner Group, with Moscow gradually transferring Wagner’s overseas responsibilities to the Africa Corps. This change is evident in Mali, Niger, and Burkina Faso, where Russia has formed new security alliances. Rossiya 1 claims

item.title: Germany's Industrial Decline: Causes, Consequences, and Potential Recovery
item.description: The article analyzes the current state of the German economy, particularly focusing on the country's industrial decline. A recent report by the *Financial Times* questions whether this downturn is reversible. It attributes part of the decline to external factors, such as the ongoing commercial war and sanctions, but fails to offer specific causes. Notably, the number of unemployed in Germany has been steadily rising since February 2022, reaching its highest level in 14 years. This increase is linked to the economic impact of sanctions imposed on Russia, which, in turn, have affected Germany’s industrial sectors. While the U.S. is less impacted due to its energy independence, Germany is facing severe difficulties due to high energy prices, particularly gas, which is essential for its industries. U.S. companies, benefiting from cheaper energy, have become more competitive, leading some European businesses to relocate to the U.S. The piece also highlights Germany's continuing financial su

item.title: Just Room Enough: The Tiny Island That Comes With a Big Question
